articles.headline: Stock Market Ends Sharply Lower as Worries About Economy Surface
articles.snippet: The benchmark Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index has slipped 8 percent this year, as concerns grow that the United States economy may be on the verge of a slowdown.
articles.abstract: The benchmark Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index has slipped 8 percent this year, as concerns grow that the United States economy may be on the verge of a slowdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: It may be time for everyone to take the markets seriously again.

articles.headline: Concealing the Calculus of Higher Education
articles.snippet: Choosing which school to attend is one of the biggest financial decisions that many people will ever make. Why are some schools making it harder to compare the potential costs?
articles.abstract: Choosing which school to attend is one of the biggest financial decisions that many people will ever make. Why are some schools making it harder to compare the potential costs?
articles.lead_paragraph: An undergraduate degree from a flagship state university often comes with a six-figure sticker price for on-campus residents. A private college could cost a quarter of a million dollars nowadays.

articles.headline: Stock Prices Sink in a Rising Ocean of Oil
articles.snippet: As an oil glut grows despite production cuts, investors worry about a slowdown in the global economy.
articles.abstract: As an oil glut grows despite production cuts, investors worry about a slowdown in the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The world is awash in crude oil, with enough extra produced last year to fuel all of Britain or Thailand. And the price of oil will not stop falling until the glut shrinks.

articles.headline: At Least 20 Killed in Siege by Militants in Burkina Faso
articles.snippet: Al Qaeda’s affiliate in North Africa claimed responsibility for the attack on a hotel popular with Westerners. An official said 22 people were dead.
articles.abstract: Al Qaeda’s affiliate in North Africa claimed responsibility for the attack on a hotel popular with Westerners. An official said 22 people were dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Gunmen from Al Qaeda stormed a luxury hotel frequented by foreigners in Burkina Faso’s capital on Friday night, seizing hostages and killing others while fighting with dozens of security forces who began a counterattack hours later. It was Al Qaeda’s first major attack in this landlocked sub-Saharan country, a former French colony.
articles.byline: By Thibault Bluy, Dionne Searcey and Rukmini Callimachi

articles.headline: China Embraces Craft Beers, and Brewing Giants Take Notice
articles.snippet: Chinese consumers are swapping mass-produced local beers for a bevy of imports and locally brewed brands, and a merged Anheuser-Busch InBev-SABMiller aims to capitalize.
articles.abstract: Chinese consumers are swapping mass-produced local beers for a bevy of imports and locally brewed brands, and a merged Anheuser-Busch InBev-SABMiller aims to capitalize.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When Jin Xin first started selling imported premium beer a decade ago, his bar manager predicted that it would take a month or two just to sell a single case. But within a few years business picked up, and soon customers started frequenting the bar for its India pale ales and other European beers.
articles.byline: By Amie Tsang and Cao Li

articles.headline: Federal Reserve Started 2010 With Hope, Then Fear and Fitful Activism
articles.snippet: Worsening economic conditions in 2010 led the Federal Reserve to act to try to avoid a new recession or a deflationary trap.
articles.abstract: Worsening economic conditions in 2010 led the Federal Reserve to act to try to avoid a new recession or a deflationary trap.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When 2010 began, the United States economy seemed to be on the mend and leaders of the Federal Reserve discussed how they would unwind their extraordinary rescue efforts  from the crisis that erupted in 2008. The term “exit strategy” was mentioned 37 times in their first two policy meetings of the year.

articles.headline: Looking at Later Primaries, Bernie Sanders Works to Strengthen Black Support
articles.snippet: The Vermont senator faces a daunting problem even if he wins Iowa and New Hampshire: winning over African-American voters in the more diverse states to follow.
articles.abstract: The Vermont senator faces a daunting problem even if he wins Iowa and New Hampshire: winning over African-American voters in the more diverse states to follow.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even if he defeats Hillary Clinton in both Iowa and New Hampshire next month, Senator Bernie Sanders faces a daunting problem when the presidential race moves on to bigger, more diverse states: winning over black voters.

articles.headline: How El Chapo Was Finally Captured, Again
articles.snippet: Joaquín Guzmán Loera’s meeting with the movie star Sean Penn gave the authorities a break they needed to help recapture him. So did a big order of tacos.
articles.abstract: Joaquín Guzmán Loera’s meeting with the movie star Sean Penn gave the authorities a break they needed to help recapture him. So did a big order of tacos.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Stripped to his undershirt and covered in filth, the world’s most notorious drug lord dragged himself out of the sewers and into the middle of traffic.

articles.headline: What Donald Trump’s Plaza Deal Reveals About His White House Bid
articles.snippet: The mogul’s purchase of the Plaza Hotel in 1988 offers insight into the methods and thinking of a deal maker turned presidential candidate.
articles.abstract: The mogul’s purchase of the Plaza Hotel in 1988 offers insight into the methods and thinking of a deal maker turned presidential candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The day Donald Trump called and asked for a one-on-one meeting in the winter of 1988, Tom Barrack was a relative newcomer to the high-stakes poker game of New York real estate. He had worked for nearly two years for Robert Bass, the Texas billionaire investor, and had played an important role in winning the Plaza Hotel for his boss the year before. Mr. Trump was the country’s most quotable and ostentatious financial celebrity, a guy with a jet, a 282-foot yacht and a fondness for peach-toned marble.

articles.headline: Clinton Campaign Underestimated Sanders Strengths, Allies Say
articles.snippet: Advisers to Mrs. Clinton, including the former president Bill Clinton, believe that her campaign made serious miscalculations by failing to undercut Mr. Sanders’s message early in the race.
articles.abstract: Advisers to Mrs. Clinton, including the former president Bill Clinton, believe that her campaign made serious miscalculations by failing to undercut Mr. Sanders’s message early in the race.
articles.lead_paragraph: Advisers to Hillary Clinton, including former President Bill Clinton, believe that her campaign made serious miscalculations by forgoing early attacks on Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and failing to undercut his archliberal message before it grew into a political movement that has now put him within striking distance of beating her in Iowa and New Hampshire.

articles.headline: Iran Complies With Nuclear Deal; Sanctions Are Lifted
articles.snippet: Iran has shipped most of its nuclear fuel out of the country, destroyed the innards of a plutonium-producing reactor and mothballed more than 12,000 centrifuges.
articles.abstract: Iran has shipped most of its nuclear fuel out of the country, destroyed the innards of a plutonium-producing reactor and mothballed more than 12,000 centrifuges.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The United States and European nations lifted oil and financial sanctions on Iran on Saturday and released roughly $100 billion of its assets after international inspectors concluded that the country had followed through on promises to dismantle large sections of its nuclear program.

articles.headline: Indebted Chinese Companies Increase Pressures on Government
articles.snippet: Despite a raft of stimulus measures, China’s economy is faltering as companies like shipbuilders increasingly lose business.
articles.abstract: Despite a raft of stimulus measures, China’s economy is faltering as companies like shipbuilders increasingly lose business.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Sainty Marine Corporation started small, buying and selling a few ships in the 1980s. But Sainty Marine, a Chinese state-owned company, went on a debt-fueled binge over the last few years, opening its own shipyards and signing orders worth hundreds of millions of dollars each.

articles.headline: For Now, Self-Driving Cars Still Need Humans
articles.snippet: Vehicles are increasingly able to do routine tasks, but the problem vexing the automobile industry is how to keep drivers ready to take over the wheel when necessary.
articles.abstract: Vehicles are increasingly able to do routine tasks, but the problem vexing the automobile industry is how to keep drivers ready to take over the wheel when necessary.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — Car enthusiasts, after hearing industry executives discussing the self-driving technology being built into their vehicles, might be forgiven for thinking robotic cars will soon drive themselves out of auto showrooms.

articles.headline: Education Technology Graduates From the Classroom to the Boardroom
articles.snippet: Much of the money pouring into ed tech is going to start-ups focused on corporate training or professional skills, creating greater financing hurdles for companies that develop apps for school use.
articles.abstract: Much of the money pouring into ed tech is going to start-ups focused on corporate training or professional skills, creating greater financing hurdles for companies that develop apps for school use.
articles.lead_paragraph: Judging by the number of learning apps available to classrooms around the country, the education technology market aimed at elementary through high schools is booming.

articles.headline: Netflix’s Opaque Disruption Annoys Rivals on TV
articles.snippet: Netflix’s refusal to disclose ratings has led to mounting frustration from traditional television industry executives.
articles.abstract: Netflix’s refusal to disclose ratings has led to mounting frustration from traditional television industry executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — Tensions between Netflix and traditional television networks escalated this weekend after industry executives expressed mounting frustration over Netflix’s refusal to disclose ratings.

articles.headline: U.S. Growth and Employment Data Tell Different Stories
articles.snippet: A divergence in the figures on hiring and output might be explained in part by the changing nature of the American economy.
articles.abstract: A divergence in the figures on hiring and output might be explained in part by the changing nature of the American economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Think of it as the looking-glass economy.

articles.headline: Mississippi Fights to Keep Control of Its Beleaguered Child Welfare System
articles.snippet: After failing to comply with a 2004 lawsuit, Mississippi is trying to avoid becoming the first state to have its child welfare system put in receivership.
articles.abstract: After failing to comply with a 2004 lawsuit, Mississippi is trying to avoid becoming the first state to have its child welfare system put in receivership.
articles.lead_paragraph: WAVELAND, Miss. — In 2003, a tiny girl weighing little more than 20 pounds arrived at an emergency shelter here on the gulf coast, after being shuttled between five foster homes and youth shelters in three months.
articles.byline: By Emily Palmer and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: 14 Testy Months Behind U.S. Prisoner Swap With Iran
articles.snippet: The turbulent talks were punctuated by high diplomatic drama and near-collapses before a deal for a prisoner release was finalized.
articles.abstract: The turbulent talks were punctuated by high diplomatic drama and near-collapses before a deal for a prisoner release was finalized.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a year, Obama administration officials had been meeting in secret with Iranian counterparts, seeking to free Americans imprisoned in the Islamic republic. Finally last fall, a deal for a prisoner release seemed all but sealed.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: In Democratic Debate, Hillary Clinton Challenges Bernie Sanders on Policy Shifts
articles.snippet: Hillary Clinton targeted Bernie Sanders’s electoral appeal with some of her strongest language yet in a debate on Sunday night, trying to undercut his image as an anti-political truth teller.
articles.abstract: Hillary Clinton targeted Bernie Sanders’s electoral appeal with some of her strongest language yet in a debate on Sunday night, trying to undercut his image as an anti-political truth teller.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton targeted Bernie Sanders’s electoral appeal with some of her strongest language yet in a debate on Sunday night, seizing on Mr. Sanders’s recent policy shifts on universal health care and gun control to try to undercut his image as an anti-political truth teller.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Heidi Nelson Cruz: A Political Spouse Making Sacrifices and Courting Donors
articles.snippet: Mrs. Cruz took a leave of absence from her executive position at Goldman Sachs to help her husband, Senator Ted Cruz, seek the White House.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Cruz took a leave of absence from her executive position at Goldman Sachs to help her husband, Senator Ted Cruz, seek the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Heidi Nelson Cruz stepped to the lectern in a black gown, waiting for the applause to settle. She was beaming.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Rural Oregon’s Lost Prosperity Gives Standoff a Distressed Backdrop
articles.snippet: Areas that were once economically important languish as jobs are clustered in urban centers, creating a feeling of powerlessness as their populations grow older, poorer and less educated.
articles.abstract: Areas that were once economically important languish as jobs are clustered in urban centers, creating a feeling of powerlessness as their populations grow older, poorer and less educated.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURNS, Ore. — One of the largest wood mills in the West once belched its steam on the edge of town, sawing ponderosa pine. Out in the woods, tree fallers like Tex Ward were proud and prosperous.

articles.headline: In Libya, U.S. Courts Unreliable Allies to Counter ISIS
articles.snippet: To stop the advance of the Islamic State’s potent Libyan branch, the United States and its allies have sought potential ground forces in a patchwork of militias.
articles.abstract: To stop the advance of the Islamic State’s potent Libyan branch, the United States and its allies have sought potential ground forces in a patchwork of militias.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — The American Special Operations forces expected a warm welcome when they landed at the Libyan air base where an allied militia was stationed. Instead, armed men from another militia at the base threatened to detain the commandos, forcing the Americans to evacuate.
articles.byline: By Suliman Ali Zway, Kareem Fahim and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Iran Set to Pump More Oil Into Market Glut
articles.snippet: Iran is reportedly ready to increase its output by 500,000 barrels a day, but some analysts doubt the country can deliver that level of production.
articles.abstract: Iran is reportedly ready to increase its output by 500,000 barrels a day, but some analysts doubt the country can deliver that level of production.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — With international sanctions lifted, the Iranian government called on its oil industry Monday to open the taps on production, a move that could add to a global glut of crude that has sent prices into a tailspin.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed
